State Key Laboratory of Clean Energy Utilization Zhejiang University Hangzhou 310027 China Ammonia as a carbon-free fuel has become one of the carbon-neutral visions. In order to decrease loading of expensive ruthenium (Ru) in catalysts for thermochemical ammonia synthesis at moderate conditions (300–400 °C and 5 MPa), a low-ruthenium catalyst (RuFe-CeO2 CNT) containing Ru-Fe alloy nanoclusters, cerium (Ce) dioxide nanorods, and carbon nanotubes (CNT) was synthesized through self-catalytic pyrolysis of dicyandiamide (DICY) and RuFeCe-BTC(benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylic acid) precursors. CeO2 nanorods stabilized Ru-Fe alloy phase with a high dispersion, which conferred Ru electron-rich state to enhance hydrogen activation capability. Carbon nanotubes facilitated H2 and NH3 desorption from Ru active sites to suppress intermediate poisoning for boosting catalytic activity. RuFe-CeO2 CNT catalyst prepared with a weight ratio of DICY to RuFeCe-BTC at 2 demonstrated excellent catalytic activity with a low apparent activation energy (42.11 kJ/mol), achieving an optimal ammonia production rate of 14.80 mmol·gcat -1·h-1 at 400 °C and 5 MPa. This surpassed ammonia production rate over RuFe-CeO2 catalyst (without CNT) while Ru loading was reduced by 36 %. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Carbon free fuel Thermochemical ammonia synthesis Ruthenium-iron alloy Carbon nanotube Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Green chemical energy storage is a promising vision for long-distance transport and long-term storage compared to batteries, compressed-air, and pumped hydro storage. Hydrogen has allured attention for the storage of renewable energy due to high specific energy density (120 MJ/kg). However, its low volumetric energy density restricted hydrogen storage and transportation. Ammonia (NH3), a hydrogen derivative, has higher volumetric energy density and established storage transportation system, making it a promising carbon-free energy carrier for green chemical energy storage [1]. The traditional ammonia synthesis is reliant on Haber-Bosch (H-B) process with hydrogen sourced from natural gas reforming or coal gasification (grey hydrogen). This energy intensive process is typically carried out at 400–500 °C and 15–25 MPa, which results in substantial energy consumption and high cost, with annual output of approximately 300 million tons of CO2 [2]. Therefore, it is imperative to conduct research into ammonia synthesis catalysts operating under milder conditions [3]. Ruthenium possesses nitrogen adsorption energy close to the optimum for ammonia synthesis, making it a promising catalyst material [4,5]. However, the industrial application of Ru-based catalysts is limited due to the scarcity of Ru. Reducing the size of metal particles to the nano, sub-nano or single-atom is an effective means of improving atom economy [6–8]. In order to reduce the size of Ru catalysts and enhance the performance, a variety of carriers had been investigated, including metal oxides, carbon materials and electronic compounds [9–14]. Sanil [15] utilized metal-organic frameworks as sacrificial templates to prepare ruthenium single-atom, nanocluster, and nanoparticle catalysts. This successfully promoted Ru dispersion and reduced Ru usage. However, excessively small structures can lead to high nitrogen dissociation energy barriers or cause site blockage, both of which inhibit ammonia synthesis [16,17]. To suppress hydrogen poisoning and try to break the limits of the scalar relationship, Alazar [18] mechanically mixed carbon nanotubes with Ru-based catalysts to accelerate ammonia production, but mechanical mixing resulted in weak interactions between the carbon nanotubes and the catalysts, limiting the creation of interfaces for the desorption of hydrogen and ammonia products. Based on the above analysis, to promote Ru catalyst dispersion and stability (cost reduction) while suppressing hydrogen poisoning (activity enhancement), highly dispersed Ru-Fe alloy sites were precisely synthesized on CeO2 nanorod carriers using metal-organic frameworks as precursors. Fe modulated Ru to an electron-rich state for promoting hydrogen activation. Carbon nanotubes were formed by dicyandiamide-induced autocatalytic pyrolysis to inhibit the poisoning of the Ru sites by facilitating the detachment of hydrogen-ammonia species. Microscopic analysis and activity tests revealed correlations among nitrogen doping, oxygen vacancies, electron cloud density, and catalytic activity. Activation energy and ammonia desorption experiments showed that the ruthenium-iron-cerium dioxide-carbon nanotube interface facilitates hydrogen and ammonia desorption while preventing active site poisoning. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials Cerium (III) nitrate hexahydrate (99 %), ruthenium (III) acetylacetonate (97 %), ferric nitrate nonahydrate (99 %), 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (BTC; 95 %), polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP;99 %), and dicyandiamide (DICY; 99 %) were purchased from Sigma–Aldrich Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. N,N-Dimethylformamide(DMF; 95 %) and ethanol (99 %) were purchased from Macklin. All chemicals were used as received without further purification. 2.2 Synthesis and characterization of materials The synthesis of RuFeCe-BTC was carried out as follows: 0.80 g of ruthenium (III) acetylacetonate, 0.51 g of ferric nitrate nonahydrate, 2.71 g of cerium (III) nitrate hexahydrate, and 1.26 g of benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylic acid (BTC) were dissolved in 50 mL of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) containing 5 % polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) by mass. The solution was stirred until clear, transferred to a 200 mL Teflon-lined stainless autoclave, sealed, and heated in an oven at 130 °C for 20 h. After natural cooling to room temperature, the product was separated by centrifugation, washed with DMF and methanol, and then dried at 80 °C for 12 h, yielding RuFeCe-BTC. The synthesis of FeCe-BTC followed the same procedure, except that ruthenium (III) acetylacetonate was not added and the amount of cerium (III) nitrate hexahydrate was adjusted to 3.61 g. RuFeCe-BTC was then pyrolyzed at 900 °C for 2 h in a vacuum tube furnace under an Ar atmosphere (flow rate: 20 mL/min) with a heating rate of 5 °C/min, producing powders labeled RuFe- CeO2 The synthesis of RuFe-CeO₂-CNT involved placing 1.00 g of RuFeCe-BTC and n g of dicyandiamide (n = 1, 2, 3, 4) in the downstream and upstream quarters of an alumina boat, respectively. Three-quarters of the upstream portion of the alumina boat was covered, leaving one-quarter of the downstream section exposed. The boat was then transferred to a vacuum tube furnace and pyrolyzed at 900 °C for 2 h in an Ar atmosphere (flow rate: 20 mL/min) with a heating rate of 5 °C/min. The resulting powders were labeled RuFe-CeO2 CNT-n. characterization of materials was given in the supporting information. Samples were reduced state at 500 °C and packed in a vacuum sealer inside N2-charged glove box to avoid air exposure. 2.3 Performance testing The temperature and pressure of the ammonia synthesis reactor were controlled using an electric heating jacket and a back-pressure valve, while the reaction space velocity was maintained at either 12,000 h-1 or 72,000 h-1 with a mass flow controller. The feed gas ratio was set to H2/N2 = 3:1, with a catalyst load of 50 mg diluted by 0.5 g of quartz sand, both with particle sizes between 20 and 40 mesh. The catalyst was fixed in place with asbestos packing at the top and bottom. The outlet gas of reactor was directed through a pre-prepared dilute sulfuric acid solution (0.02 M, 500 mL) for absorption. Every 30 min, the NH4⁺ concentration was measured using ion chromatography, and the absorbent solution was replaced. The ammonia synthesis rate per unit catalyst mass (mmol∙h-1∙gcat -1), the ammonia synthesis rate per unit Ru content (mmol∙h-1∙gRu -1), and the apparent activation energy of the catalyst (kJ/mol) were then calculated to evaluate the activity of the catalyst. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization The preparation process for the ammonia synthesis catalyst RuFe-CeO2 CNT is outlined in Scheme 1 . First, the nanorod precursor RuFeCe-BTC was synthesized using a hydrothermal method, which was then co-pyrolyzed with dicyandiamide under Ar atmosphere to produce RuFe-CeO2 CNT-n (n was the weight ratio of dicyandiamide to RuFeCe-BTC,.n = 1, 2, 3, 4). To investigate the effect of co-pyrolysis with varying BTC and dicyandiamide ratios on the crystal structure of catalysts, RuFe-CeO2 and RuFe-CeO2 CNT were characterized by XRD, as shown in Fig. 1 a The XRD patterns displayed diffraction peaks at 28.5 ° and 45.2 ° for all five materials, corresponding to the plane of CeO2 (111) and Fe (110), respectively. Notably, when the mass ratio of dicyandiamide to the catalyst precursor reached 4:1, two new characteristic peaks appeared in the XRD pattern of RuFe-CeO2 CNT-4 at 2θ = 15.0 ° and 25.6 °, attributed to CeFe(CN)₆ (PDF#40–0522). Meanwhile, the XRD characteristic peaks of Fe metal disappear. This observation suggested that dicyandiamide induced the autocatalytic pyrolysis of RuFeCe-BTC to produce metallic iron, which may interact with the highly dispersed Ru. However, an excess of dicyandiamide led to incomplete autocatalytic pyrolysis of the BTC precursor, formation of metal cyanides and reduction of metal active sites in the catalyst [19]. Additionally, no characteristic peaks of Ru metal were observed. This was likely due to Ru highly dispersed on the CeO2 surface, resulting in poor crystallinity, and crystal sizes below the XRD detection limit [20–22]. The molecular structures of RuFe-CeO2 and RuFe-CeO2 CNT were characterized by Raman spectroscopy, as shown in Fig. 1b The characteristic peak at 450 cm-1 for all five catalysts corresponded to the F2g vibrational mode of CeO2 with an octahedral cubic fluorite structure, while the peak at 590 cm-1 represented the oxygen vacancy (Ov) defect-induced (D) vibrational mode due to lattice distortion [23]. Additionally, the peaks at 690 cm-1 and 970 cm-1 were attributed to Ru-O-Ce and Fe-O-Ce bonds (collectively referred to as M-O-Ce bonds) [15,24]. Compared to RuFe-CeO2 CNT-1, the Raman spectrum of RuFe-CeO2 CNT-2 exhibited a red shift. This was likely due to an increased concentration of reducing gases during self-catalytic pyrolysis, which promoted the formation of surface defects on CeO2 nanorods and increased defect density through CeO2 etching. In contrast, the Raman spectra of RuFe-CeO2 CNT-3 and RuFe-CeO2 CNT-4 showed a blue shift, with the F2g vibration returning to 450 cm-1. This was possibly due to the increased carbon source from dicyandiamide during self-catalytic pyrolysis, causing the CeO2 nanorod surface to be covered by carbon fibers or carbon nanotubes. Considering that the characteristic peaks of CNT were not detected by XRD and Raman spectra, the samples may have low CNT loading on them. The morphology and crystal structure of RuFe-CeO2 CNT were further examined by SEM, as shown in Fig. 1c–f When the mass ratio of dicyandiamide to BTC precursor was 1:1, RuFe-CeO2 CNT-1 retained the CeO2 nanorod structure after self-catalytic pyrolysis. Moreover, a layer of needle-like carbon fibers was formed on the catalyst surface, but no significant carbon nanotubes were observed. Compared to RuFe-CeO2, RuFe-CeO2 CNT-1 showed increased nanoparticle aggregation on the surface, and with the average particle diameter approximately 20 nm [25]. This could be due to interactions between carbon fibers and metal oxides. Increasing the dicyandiamide/BTC mass ratio to 2:1 resulted in partial transformation of needle-like carbon fibers into distinct carbon nanotube structures on the surface of RuFe-CeO2 CNT-2. This transformation likely occurred because the higher dicyandiamide content during self-catalytic pyrolysis provided additional nitrogen and carbon sources for BTC framework carbonization [19]. Simultaneously, the aggregation of surface metal particles became more pronounced, with the average particle size increasing to approximately 180 nm. This was possibly because reducing gases from dicyandiamide decomposition further reduced the metal particles in the Ce-BTC lattice, facilitating their migration to the material surface [26]. When the mass ratio of dicyandiamide to BTC was raised to 3:1, the CeO2 nanorods in RuFe-CeO2 CNT-3 were fully exposed, with a further increase in the number of surface-grown carbon structure. Moreover, the average diameter of metal particles decreased to below 100 nm, forming nanoclusters. However, further increase in the mass ratio to 4:1 led to incomplete self-catalytic pyrolysis of the BTC precursor. This resulted in extensive growth of carbon structure, which covered the active CeO2 nanorod surfaces and reduced the number of active sites available for the ammonia synthesis reaction. The TEM, HRTEM and EDS results of RuFe-CeO2 were presented in Fig. 2 a∼c and Fig. S1 As seen from the TEM image and elemental mapping, Ru and Fe were uniformly dispersed on the CeO2 surface, and no distinct nanoparticles were observed. In Fig. 2c, lattice spacings of 0.312 nm was evident, corresponding to the plane of CeO2 (111), with no observable Ru lattice [27]. TEM, HRTEM, and EDS results of RuFe-CeO2 CNT-2 are presented in Fig. 2d–g The TEM image showed nanoclusters with diameters of 30–70 nm on the CeO2 nanorod surface, consistent with the SEM results. Additionally, carbon nanotubes approximately 20 nm in diameter were observed on the CeO2 nanorod surface. Notably, the nanoclusters on CeO2 surface were not coated by a carbon layer, indicating that RuFeCe-BTC precursor underwent complete pyrolysis during self-catalytic decomposition, leaving active sites on the oxide surface uncovered and fully exposing the Ru and Fe species [28]. Two lattice spacings of 0.315 nm and 0.202 nm were observed on CeO2 nanorod surface (Fig. 2f), corresponding to the (111) plane of CeO2 and the (110) plane of Fe, respectively. Compared to RuFe-CeO2, the lattice spacings of CeO2 on the surface of RuFe-CeO2 CNT-2 were expanded by approximately 0.003 nm. This was likely due to NH3 gas generated from dicyandiamide decomposition during self-catalytic pyrolysis, which reacted with the metal-organic framework and caused partial N doping into CeO2 lattices, inducing tensile strain [29]. In contrast to RuFe-CeO2, the EDS image of RuFe-CeO2 CNT-2 showed Ru and Fe particles exhibited distinct clustering. The chemical environment and electronic structure of Ru species were investigated by synchrotron radiation (Fig. 1(g-h) and Fig. S2). Extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) spectra in R-space and the corresponding wavelet transform (WT) provided further information on the catalyst structure. In agreement with the Ru film, the peak at 2.47 Å in RuFe-CeO2 CNT-2 corresponds to Ru-Ru scattering. The introduction of the low order atom Fe causes the interatomic spacing to contract and the peak at 2.08 Å corresponds to Ru-Fe scattering, suggesting the formation of a Ru-Fe phase [30,31]. In addition, a weak peak at 1.53 Å was detected, corresponding to Ru-O scattering, which could be attributed to Ru-O-Ce, suggesting the interaction between the Ru and CeO2 support. The characteristic Ru-(O)-Ru peak was not detected, essentially ruling out oxide formation. These results indicate the presence of a well-defined Ru-Fe alloy phase. 3.2 Autocatalytic formation of electron-rich state of Ru Oxygen vacancies possess localized electron-deficient centers that can serve as adsorption and activation sites for N₂ molecules and spillover nitrogen species. The O 1 s XPS spectrum of RuFe-CeO2 CNT (Fig. 3 a) displayed a broad peak and a shoulder peak, which can be deconvoluted into three smaller peaks. The peak at binding energy of 529.9 eV corresponded to lattice oxygen (OL), the peak at 531.7 eV to vacancy oxygen (OV), and the peak at 533.1 eV to chemisorbed oxygen (Oad) [32]. To further investigate the oxygen vacancy content in the catalyst, the XPS results were quantitatively analyzed, as shown in Table S2. As the mass ratio of dicyandiamide to the precursor increased, the content of vacancy oxygen (Ov/Ov+Oc) in the material exhibited a volcano-like trend. Increasing the mass ratio of dicyandiamide to precursor provided additional nitrogen sources, further enhancing the oxygen vacancy content in the material [33–35]. When the mass ratio reached 2:1, the material (RuFe-CeO2 CNT-2) exhibited the highest oxygen vacancy content (26 %). Further increase in dicyandiamide content led to excess carbon source during pyrolysis, resulting in the formation of excessive carbon structures on the surface. This may be the reason for decreased oxygen vacancy content in RuFe-CeO2 CNT-3 and RuFe-CeO2 CNT-4. The high-resolution Fe 2p spectrum of RuFe-CeO2 CNT (Fig. 3b) displayed two broad peaks that can be deconvoluted into six distinct peaks, including characteristic peaks for Fe2+ and Fe3+ species, as well as two satellite peaks [36,37]. The Fe 2p energy levels in the material exhibited a “volcano-type” trend. As the mass ratio of dicyandiamide to precursor increased from 1:1 to 2:1, the Fe 2p spectrum shifted 0.3 eV towards lower energy levels. With further increase in dicyandiamide content, the spectrum shifted to higher energy levels, surpassing that of RuFe-CeO2 CNT-1. The Fe 2p energy level initially decreased and then increased, combined with XRD, which could be attributed to the successive formation of Fe and CeFe(CN)6. Dicyandiamide induced the autocatalytic pyrolysis of RuFeCe-BTC to produce metallic iron, while an excess of dicyandiamide led to metal cyanides. As shown in Fig. 3c, Ru 3p spectrum of RuFe-CeO2 CNT displayed four sharp peaks that can be deconvoluted into six peaks, including characteristic peaks for Ru2+, Ru4+, and Ru6+ species [38]. Similar to the Fe 2p spectrum, the Ru 3p energy levels of RuFe-CeO2 CNT exhibited a “volcano-type” trend. Specifically, RuFe-CeO2 CNT-2 and RuFe-CeO2 CNT-3 showed the lowest energy levels, indicating the highest electron cloud density for Ru species. The trend of Ru3p spectrum was consistent with that of Fe 2p spectrum, suggesting that self-catalytic pyrolysis similarly promoted the formation of electron-rich Ru species, thereby enhancing electron transfer at Ru active sites during ammonia synthesis. The Ce 3d XPS spectrum of RuFe-CeO2 CNT (Fig. 3d) displayed four sharp peaks and two shoulder peaks, which can be deconvoluted into nine distinct peaks. The peaks at binding energies of 882.9 eV, 889.4 eV, 901.6 eV, 907.9 eV, and 916.9 eV corresponded to Ce4+, while those at 881.8 eV, 885.4 eV, 898.9 eV, and 904.3 eV were derived from Ce3+ [39]. For the four catalysts, the Ce3+/Ce4+ ratios were 0.64, 0.85, 0.71, and 0.73, with RuFe-CeO2 CNT-2 exhibiting the highest Ce3+ content. This is consistent with the fact that O 1 s XPS spectrum exhibits the highest content of oxygen vacancies. The high-resolution C 1 s orbital spectra of RuFe-CeO2 CNTs are shown in Fig. 3e When the mass ratio of dicyandiamide to the precursor is different, the C 1 s energy spectra all show a large peak which can be folded into three small peaks at 284.8 eV, 285.3 eV and 286.8 eV, respectively, corresponding to the C=C bond, C=N bond and CO bond, which indicated that a carbon fiber or carbon nanotube structure exists on the surface of CeO2 nanorods. XANES of RuFe-CeO2 CNT-2 presented more information about the electronic structure of Ru (Fig. 3f). The absorption edge of RuFe-CeO2 CNT-2 shifted to higher energies between Ru foils and Ru oxides, and we deduced that the Ru-Fe interaction exists. The above results show that Fe donates electrons to Ru to form an electron-rich Ru species [31]. 3.3 Enhancement of hydrogen and ammonia desorption by carbon nanotubes In-situ grown carbon nanotubes could serve as bridges for transporting intermediate species between metal active sites and oxide supports [40]. Analysis of the H2-TPD and NH3-TPD profiles of various catalysts enabled differentiation of their abilities to provide activated hydrogen and ammonia products. RuFe-CeO2 exhibited an H2 desorption peak at 233 °C (Fig. 4 a), while RuFe-CeO2 CNT showed a peak at 166 °C. The quantification of absorbed H2 was conducted by integrating the peak area in the range of 323–673 K. The H2 adsorption amounts for RuFe-CeO2 and RuFe-CeO2 CNT were 1.1 and 2.2 µmol∙gcat -1, respectively. The desorption peak shift to lower temperature suggested that carbon nanotubes facilitated hydrogen desorption, while the increased desorption area indicated that carbon nanotubes acted as storage carriers and transport channels for active hydrogen species [41]. The NH3-TPD curves of both RuFe-CeO2 and RuFe-CeO2 CNT-2 (Fig. 4b) exhibited a weak acidic desorption peak in the 0–150 °C range, attributed to NH3 desorption from carbon nanotubes and CeO2. Additionally, RuFe-CeO2 and RuFe-CeO2 CNT-2 showed moderate acidic desorption peaks at 398 °C and 386 °C, respectively, corresponding to NH3 desorption from Ru species. The shift of the desorption peak to a lower temperature suggested that the carbon nanotubes, functioning as bridges, facilitated the desorption of NH3 adsorbed on the metal sites. These findings indicated that carbon nanotubes, enhanced the desorption of H2 and NH3 from catalyst metal sites, inhibited poisoning by intermediate products, and promoted turnover at Ru active sites. As shown in Fig. 4c, N2-TPD was used to investigate the N2 desorption performance of RuFe-CeO2 CNT-2 and RuFe-CeO2 catalysts. The peak observed at 96 °C was attributed to weakly physical adsorbed N2, while the desorption peak at 144 °C corresponds to strongly chemically adsorbed N2. RuFe-CeO2–CNT-2 exhibited a stronger N2 desorption signal than RuFe-CeO2, suggesting RuFe-CeO2–CNT-2 with more favorable N2 adsorption, which might promote N2 adsorption and improve the catalytic performance. 3.4 Catalytic activity for NH3 synthesis The ammonia synthesis rate and Ru content of catalysts with varying dicyandiamide ratios were calculated (Figs. 5 a). As dicyandiamide ratio increased, the mass fraction of metallic Ru in RuFe-CeO2 CNT catalyst gradually decreased, and the ammonia synthesis rate exhibited a volcano-shaped trend. RuFe-CeO2 CNT-2 demonstrated the highest catalytic activity, likely because carbon nanotubes facilitated the desorption of NH3 and H2, thereby enhancing Ru site turnover. Further increase in dicyandiamide ratio resulted in excessive growth of metal cyanide and carbon fibers on the material surface, which covered active sites and reduced catalytic activity. As shown in Fig. 5b, the activity of RuFe-CeO2 CNT-2 catalyst (4753 mmol∙gRu -1∙h-1) exceeded that of RuFe-CeO2 catalyst (2933 mmol∙gRu -1∙h-1) Thus, self-catalytic pyrolysis can significantly reduce catalyst costs through less precious metal loading. As shown in Table S3, the NH3 production rates percent Ru of RuFe-CeO2 CNT-2 was higher than that of other Ru-based catalysts. The effect of temperature on the catalytic activity of RuFeCeO2 catalyst was tested at a pressure of 1 MPa, and the apparent activation energies of various RuFe-CeO2 CNT catalysts were calculated using the Arrhenius plot, as shown in Fig. 5c-d. RuFe-CeO2 CNT-2 displayed the lowest apparent activation energy (42.11 kJ/mol), and that of RuFe-CeO2 CNT-1 (49.27 kJ/mol) was only slightly higher. In contrast, RuFe-CeO2 CNT-3 exhibited a considerably higher apparent activation energy (82.73 kJ/mol), approaching the values reported for Fe-based ammonia synthesis catalysts [42]. The stability test results for RuFe-CeO2 CNT-2 catalyst under optimal conditions (400 °C, 5 MPa) are presented in Fig. 6 a. Over 72 h, the ammonia synthesis rate of RuFe-CeO2 CNT-2 catalyst remained stable, ranging from 13.84 to 14.80 mmol∙gcat -1∙h-1. SEM images of RuFe-CeO2 CNT-2 catalyst before and after the reaction (Fig. 6b and 6c) revealed no significant changes in the CeO2 nanorod structure and a certain amount of CNT remains on the surface., further confirming its stability. 4 Conclusion This study designed a new Ru-based catalyst for ammonia synthesis with low content of precious metal. The catalyst was synthesized through self-catalytic pyrolysis and consisted of highly dispersed Ru-Fe alloy nanoclusters, cerium dioxide nanorods, and carbon nanotubes. The cerium dioxide nanorods stabilized the Ru-Fe nanoclusters, achieving a high dispersion. Fe rendered Ru electron-rich, improving its hydrogen activation capability. H2-TPD and NH3-TPD tests demonstrated that the carbon nanotubes on the surface facilitated desorption and transport of intermediates, thereby enhancing Ru site turnover. Performance tests showed that RuFe-CeO2 CNT-2 possessed a low apparent activation energy (42.11 kJ/mol) and reached an optimal ammonia synthesis rate of 14.80 mmol∙gcat -1∙h-1 at 400 °C and 5 MPa, with a significantly higher activity than RuFe-CeO2 and a 36 % reduction in Ru loading. Stability tests confirmed that RuFe-CeO2 CNT-2 maintained a consistent ammonia synthesis rate between 13.84 and 14.80 mmol∙gcat -1∙h-1 over a 72-hour period. The approach proposed in this work may be valuable for designing and synthesizing other efficient and low-cost catalysts with reduced precious metal content. coredata.dc:description: Ammonia as a carbon-free fuel has become one of the carbon-neutral visions. In order to decrease loading of expensive ruthenium (Ru) in catalysts for thermochemical ammonia synthesis at moderate conditions (300–400 °C and 5 MPa), a low-ruthenium catalyst (RuFe-CeO2 CNT) containing Ru-Fe alloy nanoclusters, cerium (Ce) dioxide nanorods, and carbon nanotubes (CNT) was synthesized through self-catalytic pyrolysis of dicyandiamide (DICY) and RuFeCe-BTC(benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylic acid) precursors. CeO2 nanorods stabilized Ru-Fe alloy phase with a high dispersion, which conferred Ru electron-rich state to enhance hydrogen activation capability. Carbon nanotubes facilitated H2 and NH3 desorption from Ru active sites to suppress intermediate poisoning for boosting catalytic activity. RuFe-CeO2 CNT catalyst prepared with a weight ratio of DICY to RuFeCe-BTC at 2 demonstrated excellent catalytic activity with a low apparent activation energy (42.11 kJ/mol), achieving an optimal ammonia production rate of 14.80 mmol·gcat -1·h-1 at 400 °C and 5 MPa. This surpassed ammonia production rate over RuFe-CeO2 catalyst (without CNT) while Ru loading was reduced by 36 %.
